comments.commentBody:

I've never liked you.
Stuck on the phone with my psychic.
Having a lobotomy reversal.

My homework ate my dog...
(Well, you know, if the teacher told you to take care of the class iguana for the weekend...)

Sometimes the best excuse is to act as though none is needed. Some years ago, while visiting Thailand, I spent the night at a rustic though not-all-that-inexpensive hotel by the beach at Phuket. In the middle of the night I woke with a start as something scurried across my feet. I flicked on the light just in time to see a large, brown rat clambering up the drapes. Throwing on a robe, I ran down the hall to the front desk.

"There's a rat in my room!" I exclaim.

The desk clerk looks at me expectantly. "Yes?"

"In my room. On my bed. A rat!"

"Yes, sir. A rat." She waits.

"Yes! A..." I sense a communication problem, and shift to hand gestures. "Yes, like this," I say, carving out a little air-rat with my hands, finger-walking it across the counter. "Furry, brown."

The clerks face seems to light up for a moment. "Ah! A rat?"

"Yes, you see, like this." I am making little rat motions now, pantomiming rattiness. "It was chewing on my toes." I make my best rat-face, wrinkle my nose and make beaver-y gnawing motions.

The clerk gives me a patient smile. "Yes, sir, a rat." She pauses. "Will there be anything else?"

I am perplexed, and I realize, defeated. I may as well have reported a mini-bar in my room. I start back, but then turn to the clerk.

"May I have a broom?"

"Why, sir? Has there been a spill? Shall I summon housekeeping?"

"No. That's all right. I'll handle it myself," I tell her.

And walk slowly back to my room, muttering to myself. "But of course there's a rat, you fool. It was complimentary, don't you know? Tourists!"
oh, we lost your key because one of our agents accidentally dropped it down the elevator shaft after a showing.
"'I  did clean my room.  Well...at least by Exxon standards...' Pretty slick, huh?" from Graham Baird's Speech "Passing the Buck."

The Jets have made a lot of very shrewd personnel decisions since Mike Tannenbaum took over as GM, whether it be via draft, trades, free agent signings or waiver deals, but this deserves to be on the Mt. Rushmore of bone-headed moves.  Tony Richardson is still one of the best fullbacks in the game, he was the most seasoned vet on the team and well liked by all.  True, Conner looks like he's starting caliber, but sometimes a player's contributions to the chemistry in the locker room, as well as his ability to bridge the maturity gap between coaches and players can't be measured the same way his on-field production can be.  A gimmicky move to cut and then attempt to resign the locker room's elder statesman in order to avoid guaranteeing his less than $1M salary will have huge ramifications in the way the players view management.

It is important not to over-react.

The 2009 Jets did not jell until week 12 when they ground out a tough win against Carolina, and only a last-play Tony Gonzalez touchdown interrupted a perfect close-out to the season. This team was a steamroller from that point on.

There are already many reasons why the 2010 Jets may need similar time to come together. High among them is the need for ownership to emerge, for leadership to rise from the ranks. This is true for most teams every several seasons, rare exceptions being those players who lead their teams for much longer. Rarer still among Jets.

To the naked eye, we see plenty of leadership being cut and plenty of responsibility handed to newcomers. We are likely to see, in the first part of the season, this team grasp about for leadership and consistency. We may be inclined to scream to the high heavens, why did we let this or that player go?

There is no faster maturation process than the first year in the NFL. You start as a baby and you come out as a man. There is a reason they say "there are no rookies in the post-season;" their rookie season was the regular season; the post-season is their second season and they know what to do by now.

In other words, young players make great leaps in their first NFL season. If you have the right guys, then you expect them to rise to the level expected of an NFL player and you expect them to jell as a team.

You would like to see it happen sooner than later, but as 2009's Jets demonstrated, just get into the tournament, baby.

I will not be shocked to see a 4-4 record after 8 games. Certainly we need to get the roster squared away and we need time to cohere, so that to me is the first half of the season.

The second half I look forward to at least 6 wins, and I hope that 10 wins gets you in.

So the moral of the story is, don't be so quick to criticize the lack of leadership and consistency at the start of the season. The organization has made a bet that these things will emerge, and so we can to some extent allow that process to unfold and look at progress as much in that was as in the W/L column, at lest at the outset.

If this season falls apart, we can all look back at the end and admit that too many risks were taken with lack of continuity.

On the other hand, if these guys rise to the opportunities they're being given, this could be a mighty exciting and in some sense era-defining year for this franchise.

Parting ways is definitely hard to do, but we have to have faith in the newcomers. They're our guys now, and the organization chose to go with them instead of the veterans. It's a leap of faith we must take, because the alternative is what happened during the Herm Edwards era, when a ruthless purge was so sorely needed and there was all that guaranteed money to deal with.

I don't expect many takers for a return to that era.

Lots of folks seemed to like this puzzle and I just didn't, and I'm not sure why. Maybe because I knew neither CRAKE nor OMSK and felt cheated of vistory, especially since the latter must be a recurring fill. I also felt a bit aggrieved that a solution depended on knowing both an Eminem song and a Van Wilder movie character, about which people my age are clueless, so to speak. But except for the excellent Othello LIVING MOOR, I didn't find a lot of really clever stuff here, and the 'backwards' theme was too reminiscent of the very tough Thursday puzzler just a couple days ago.
I enjoyed the puzzle, but what sort of pot belongs on what kind of sill?

The headline says it all.

Revis came down from the clouds. By his numbers 4 years should have been worth at least 60 million.

The Jets got their man at a realistic number.

Let's give credit where due.

Nobody wants to be a doubles player. It's like rhythmic gymnastics. You only become a rhythmic gymnast because you are not good enough or too big to do REAL gymnastics. The same goes for doubles. Doubles is for second rate singles players or for first rate singles players for fun.

Completely agree with this article

Sure bounce + sure footing takes the sting out of Nadal's game.

How did Rafa win the Australian Open? Rubbery court surface gives a higher bounce + Rafa is fully rested at the beginning of the season.

As Rafa said in answer to that stupid question 'Did he get out of the van that had Roger's picture on it?' - "Yeah, well, if you know me, you know that I not gonna do [that]". What is it with the media nowadays that they want to make up phony stories just for sensationalism? Rafa is the most humble star on the tour and doesn't get off on ego trips.

With such important things like winning the US Open to be concerned about, he doesn't need the hassles of false rumors, but at least the organizers of the tournament and all his fans know that the story is just a crazy lie. Vamos Rafa, and good luck in your next match. Can hardly wait to see you lifting that trophy next Sunday!

The point of admiring the style and grace that a few professional players still employ is that tennis can be a beautiful game.  But at the professional level, it rarely is anymore.  With so many things in our world today, beauty is a runner up to efficiency.  Tennis is no exception.  The technological changes made to the rackets and courts express this favoring of utility over artistry, force over imagination.  I went out to Flushing Meadow yesterday specifically to see the match between Schnyder and Wickmayer.  I knew it would be a perfect example of this clash of paradigms.  I was not disappointed -- even if irrepressible youth edged out wily experience by a couple of points.   And I was especially pleased to have one more chance to admire the inventive play of Patty Schynder, one of the last her breed, now certainly in the final chapter of her career.

I'm a big Michigan fan.  Don't think RR is a Michigan man and I don't think he can run a quarterback that often without wrecking him.  I loved the win, but that quarterback, as nice as he seems to be, won't last the season at this rate.  The Big 10 is not the semi-pro league that the SEC has become, because maybe they care too much about graduating players.  But there's some big, fast kids that'll eventually fall on that quarterback.

Trust me, the major conference teams could afford taking a one-time dollar hit and play at Boise IF they were seeking out good competition. They fill their schedules with home guarantee games against inferior programs and the fees they pay out are nowhere near $1.25 mill. It's a disgrace - a rip-off for fans - but nowadays money trumps competition. There are few schools left which will take on all comers; USC, Georgia, Colorado, and a couple of others. Boise's misfortune is that they got real good in a decadant era.

Boise's come a long way, douglaso. Even so, how about a return match between BSU and VT in, say, Salt Lake City? Or even Denver? Lots of larger venues are close enough to Boise to make them as much a home field as Landover will be for VT. Fair's fair. I don't believe BSU will win this game, and I don't believe that BSU, Utah, TCU, BYU, etc, belong at the top of the ratings. But it's time the BCS teams stopped dodging these guys and made them prove it on the field. Consistently. C'mon, BCS teams. Do the home-and-home!
Where are the "drag Kings"?
